sections.title: In-house 3D printing for restorative dentistry
sections.body: A clinician-led printing lab producing guides, provisionals, guards, and restorations with controlled materials and timelines.
bullets: Scans feed directly into our print workflows
Trial prints for verification before final fit
Materials selected for their intended indications
Option to escalate to lab ceramics when required

sections.title: Quality controlled, clinician directed
items: Design and print decisions made chairside with you
Reduced remakes through test prints and checks
Material traceability and regulated indications
Faster turnaround while keeping fit standards high
Transparent advice when lab-made options are preferred

sections.title: Printed guides, provisionals, and protective devices
sections.body: Our in-house lab produces restorative guides, try-in veneers, implant provisionals, dentures, and mouth guards under clinician oversight. Porcelain and lab ceramics remain the standard when long-term aesthetics and wear demand it.
bullets: Printed mock-ups for veneers and smile previews
Guides and provisionals for implant and restorative work
Clear pathways to lab ceramics where they serve best

sections.title: Patients needing precise, timely printed solutions
items: Those wanting digital previews before committing
Implant patients needing guided provisionals
People requiring fast-turnaround dentures or guards
Patients balancing cost with clinician-led quality
Anyone needing clarity on when to upgrade to ceramic

sections.title: Scan, design, print, and fit
items: Digital consultation and scan
Design review with material guidance
Printing and test fitting
Refinement and finishing under clinician direction
Fit appointment with bite and comfort checks
Maintenance plan and upgrade options when appropriate
sections.strapline: We explain timelines upfront, including when external lab work is the better choice.

sections.title: Integrated scan-to-print workflows
sections.body: Scans flow into design software and calibrated printers, with finishing guided by the clinical team to protect accuracy and comfort. Materials are chosen for the indication and verified before fit.

sections.title: Keeping printed devices performing
items: Cleaning guidance specific to each printed device
Bite checks where relevant to protect restorations
Material wear monitoring with clear replacement timelines
Advice on when to move to ceramic or metal alternatives
Rapid adjustments available if comfort changes

faqs.question: Are printed devices as strong as lab ceramics?
faqs.answer: Printed materials are selected for specific indications and can be very durable. For certain long-term aesthetic or high-load cases, lab ceramics may still be recommended.

faqs.question: How fast can items be produced?
faqs.answer: In-house control shortens turnaround. We share expected timelines and confirm when external lab work is needed.

faqs.question: Do you keep records of the designs?
faqs.answer: Yes. We store digital files so remakes or adjustments follow the original plan without guesswork.

faqs.question: What materials do you use?
faqs.answer: We use regulated dental-grade resins and materials suitable for their intended use and explain maintenance requirements.

faqs.question: Can I upgrade later?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. We outline when transitioning to ceramic or metal alternatives benefits longevity or aesthetics.

sections.title: See what our 3D printing lab can make for you
sections.body: Book a digital consultation to review whether in-house printing, provisional work, or lab ceramics will best support your treatment.
